questions.question: A 6-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department after a sudden onset of fever, vomiting, and irritability. The child’s parents report that he had a productive cough and runny nose for the past few days, which seemed to improve before the acute deterioration. On examination, the child appears lethargic and is febrile (39°C or 102.2°F). There is hypotension (blood pressure 85/50 mmHg), and he is tachycardic (heart rate 120 bpm). Physical examination reveals diffuse petechial rashes on the lower extremities and trunk. Laboratory findings show: WBC count : 18,000/µL (elevated) Blood cultures : Which laboratory finding is most commonly associated with Waterhouse-Friderichsen syndrome?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Hyponatremia Explanation: Hyponatremia is commonly observed in adrenal insufficiency. Waterhouse-Friderichsen Syndrome Adrenal insufficiency with bilateral adrenal hemorrhage. Etiopathogenesis: Most commonly associated with Neisseria meningitidis (meningococcal infection). Other bacteria that may cause WFS include Streptococcus pneumoniae Haemophilus influenzae Staphylococcus aureus.

questions.question: A 42-year-old woman presents to your clinic with complaints of progressive fatigue, headaches, and increased skin pigmentation over the past few months. She has a history of Cushing's disease, which was diagnosed 4 years ago, and underwent a bilateral adrenalectomy. Upon physical examination, she appears lethargic and has a noticeable darkening of the skin around her neck and on her palms. She also mentions new-onset visual disturbances. Which of the following is false about her condition?

options.A: Visual disturbances are due to Nerve compression

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Very low ACTH levels Explanation: ACTH levels are very high in Nelson syndrome Nelson syndrome/post-adrenalectomy syndrome: Definition Nelson's syndrome is a condition that typically occurs after bilateral adrenalectomy for the treatment of Cushing's disease (pituitary-dependent Cushing’s syndrome). The removal of the adrenal glands leads to a lack of negative feedback on the pituitary, resulting in increased secretion of ACTH . Over time, the pituitary gland may develop a pituitary adenoma (or enlargement of an existing adenoma), which secretes ACTH in excess. (Option C and D ruled out) Prevention Prophylactic radiation therapy may be indicated to prevent the development of Nelson’s syndrome after adrenalectomy Clinical features Hyperpigmentation Bitemporal hemianopia Progressive visual loss in cases of large tumors (Option A ruled out) Headache Weakness and fatigue Inhibition of the release of other pituitary hormones Evaluation Fasting Plasma ACTH Levels: Very high levels. (Option B) Diagnosis confirmed by an ACTH increase >30% of the initial result on three consecutive samples after bilateral adrenalectomy. Decreased levels of anterior pituitary hormones . Brain MRI shows pituitary tumors or enlargement of existing tumors. Screening: Regular screening with fasting plasma ACTH levels and brain MRI in patients after bilateral adrenalectomy. Management Surgical Removal of the Tumor Radiotherapy / Radiosurgery Medical Treatment Hormonal Replacement Therapy Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page 2916 https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK560755/

questions.question: A 45-year-old man with a confirmed diagnosis of Cushing's disease presents with symptoms of central obesity, hypertension, and muscle weakness. Imaging reveals a 5 mm pituitary adenoma. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial treatment approach for this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Selective transsphenoidal surgery Explanation: Selective transsphenoidal surgery is the preferred initial treatment for Cushing’s disease caused by a pituitary adenoma. Treatment and Management The approach to managing Cushing's syndrome depends on accurate diagnosis and identifying the underlying cause. Initial Steps of Workup Exclude exogenous glucocorticoid use as the source of symptoms. Conduct thorough clinical assessment and laboratory testing to confirm Cushing's syndrome. Determine whether the cortisol excess is ACTH-dependent or ACTH-independent using plasma ACTH levels. Perform appropriate imaging (pituitary MRI for ACTH-dependent, adrenal CT for ACTH-independent) to visualize potential tumors. Employ further tests like the dexamethasone suppression test, CRH test, and inferior petrosal sinus sampling (IPSS) to differentiate between Cushing's disease and ectopic ACTH syndrome. I) Surgery : The preferred treatment for most cases. Cushing's disease: Selective transsphenoidal surgery (Option C) to remove the pituitary adenoma, the preferred initial treatment for Cushing’s disease caused by a pituitary adenoma. Adrenocortical adenoma: Laparoscopic/ Open adrenalectomy, depending on size. Ectopic ACTH syndrome: Surgical removal of the ACTH-secreting tumor , if locatable. Bilateral Adrenalectomy: Considered in cases of ectopic ACTH syndrome where the tumor source cannot be located . Requires lifelong corticosteroid replacement. (Option B ruled out) II) Medical Therapy : Used to control cortisol levels pre-operatively or in cases where surgery is not feasible, like Refractory hyperkalemic hypertension, Acute psychosis, Undetected ectopic, Metastasis Metyrapone and ketoconazole (Option A ruled out) : Inhibit cortisol synthesis. Osilodrostat : A potent 11 β -hydroxylase inhibitor. Mitotane : An adrenolytic agent, often used for ACC. Etomidate : Blocks 11 β -hydroxylase, administered intravenously. Pasireotide : A somatostatin receptor agonist, used for Cushing's disease when surgery is not successful. (Option D ruled out) III) Post-Surgical Management: Hydrocortisone replacement is necessary after surgery to address HPA axis suppression. The recovery of the HPA axis can take months or even years, and in some cases, may not fully recover. IV) Long-term Monitoring: Essential to detect recurrence and manage potential complications. Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page 3000- 3008

questions.question: A 45-year-old woman presents with weight gain, fatigue and difficulty climbing stairs. On physical examination, she has central obesity, a rounded face and broad purple striae on her abdomen. The internist suspects the case to be Cushing's syndrome. What is the most likely additional clinical feature associated with this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Osteoporosis Explanation Cushing's syndrome can be associated with bone resorption and reduced bone formation due to high levels of cortisol. Clinical Features of Cushing syndrome Physical : Weight gain and central obesity : Particularly around the face ( "moon facies" ) and the back of the neck ( "buffalo hump" ). Skin changes: Thin and fragile skin prone to bruising, broad purple stretch marks, acne, and hirsutism. Musculoskeletal Issues: Osteoporosis (leading to fractures, especially in the spine) (Option B) , muscle weakness, and proximal myopathy (difficulty climbing stairs or rising from a chair), decreased deep tendon reflexes (Option C ruled out) Metabolic : Glucose intolerance or diabetes and dyslipidemia (abnormal blood lipid levels). Cardiovascular : Hypertension (Option A ruled out) , hypokalemia , and edema. Reproductive: Decreased libido , and amenorrhea in women due to suppressed gonadotropin release. Psychological : Irritability, emotional instability, depression, cognitive impairment, and in severe cases, psychosis. Other features: Increased susceptibility to infections, elevated white blood cell count (Option D ruled out) , eosinopenia Hypercoagulable state, increasing the risk of deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism. Reference: Harrison's principles of internal medicine, 21st Edition, Page 3000- 3008

questions.question: A 52-year-old man presents with symptoms of weight gain, central obesity, hypertension, purple abdominal striae, hyperpigmentation of knuckles, and muscle weakness. Imaging reveals a lung mass. Which of the following is the most likely cause in this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Ectopic ACTH secretion Explanation: The presence of elevated ACTH levels and a lung mass strongly suggests ectopic ACTH production, which is often associated with neuroendocrine tumors such as small-cell lung carcinoma. These tumors secrete ACTH outside the normal hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal axis, causing hypercortisolism and Cushing's syndrome. Cushing's syndrome: Cushing's syndrome is a collection of symptoms resulting from prolonged exposure to high levels of glucocorticoids. Cushing's disease specifically refers to Cushing's syndrome caused by a pituitary corticotrope adenoma. It is relatively rare, but mild cases may be more common, particularly among those with symptoms like central obesity, type 2 diabetes and osteoporosis. Hyperpigmentation of knuckles: Central obesity with broad purple stretch marks: Causes: Cushing's syndrome can be caused by various factors, categorised as ACTH-dependent or ACTH-independent. I) ACTH-dependent Cushing's Syndrome accounts for approximately 90% of cases. Cushing's disease (ACTH-producing pituitary adenoma) is the most common cause. Ectopic ACTH syndrome occurs when a non-pituitary tumour secretes ACTH . II) ACTH-independent Cushing's Syndrome constitutes the remaining 10% of cases. Adrenocortical adenoma is the most prevalent cause, accounting for 5–10% of all cases. Rare causes include: Primary bilateral macronodular adrenal hyperplasia (PBMAH) Primary pigmented nodular adrenal disease (PPNAD) McCune-Albright syndrome

questions.question: A patient with a history of neuroendocrine tumors (NETs) presents with symptoms of carcinoid syndrome, including frequent episodes of watery diarrhea and flushing. Which of the following is the most appropriate first-line treatment to control these symptoms, particularly diarrhea?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Somatostatin analogues Explanation : Somatostatin analogues are the first-line treatment for carcinoid syndrome. They work by inhibiting the secretion of serotonin and other hormones responsible for symptoms like diarrhea and flushing. Carcinoid Syndrome Carcinoid syndrome is caused by hormone secretion (mainly serotonin ) from neuroendocrine tumors (NETs). Commonly arises from NETs in the small intestine or appendix . The syndrome typically occurs when the tumor has metastasized to the liver or retroperitoneum, allowing the hormones to enter systemic circulation. Histamine and tachykinins (e.g., substance P) may also contribute to the syndrome. Common Symptoms Flushing: Sudden onset of an intense red or purplish color, especially on the upper body, neck, and face, often with a sensation of warmth. Diarrhea: Frequent watery stools, often over 10 times/day, significantly impacting daily life. Less Common Symptoms Wheezing or asthma-like symptoms Impaired cognitive function in advanced cases Pellagra-like skin lesions due to niacin deficiency (from tryptophan being used to produce serotonin instead of niacin). Management Somatostatin analogues : Mainstay treatment that mimics somatostatin , which inhibits hormone secretion (e.g., serotonin). Most NETs (around 90%) have somatostatin receptors and respond to these analogues. Telotristat ethyl : Blocks serotonin production; used as adjunctive therapy for patients who don't fully respond to somatostatin analogues. (Option B ruled out) Surgery: Considered for localized tumors but often not possible in patients with metastatic disease. Loperamide (Option A): It is a conventional antidiarrhoeal agent that slows intestinal motility. However, it is not the first-line treatment for carcinoid syndrome because it does not address the underlying cause, which is the excessive secretion of hormones like serotonin by the neuroendocrine tumor. Antihistamines (Option D): Antihistamines may be used in cases where histamine secretion contributes to symptoms, but they are not effective in controlling the serotonin-mediated diarrhea characteristic of carcinoid syndrome. Reference: Harrison's principles of internal medicine 21st Edition, Page 663- 668, 2987.

questions.question: A 35-year-old male presents to the emergency room with severe headaches, palpitations and profuse sweating. His blood pressure is measured at 180/110 mmHg. Initial biochemical testing shows elevated plasma metanephrines and catecholamines. An MRI reveals a mass in the extra-adrenal retroperitoneal area. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management strategy to control his blood pressure before surgery?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Phenoxybenzamine Explanation: Phenoxybenzamine is the first-line agent for blood pressure control in patients with catecholamine-secreting tumors, such as pheochromocytomas or paragangliomas. A non-selective alpha-adrenergic blocker. It reduces vasoconstriction and prevents hypertensive crises by blocking alpha receptors. It is used preoperatively to stabilize blood pressure and avoid life-threatening complications during surgery. Paraganglioma Catecholamine-producing tumors from sympathetic or parasympathetic nervous systems. Can be sporadic or hereditary (25-33% linked to MEN 2, VHL syndromes). Location: Skull base and neck. Called pheochromocytomas if present in retroperitoneal, pelvic, and thoracic regions. Clinical Features Referred to as " the great masquerader " due to variable presentation. Common symptoms: Headaches, sweating, palpitations, tachycardia, hypertension, anxiety, panic attacks. Hypertension is the main sign (can lead to heart failure, pulmonary edema, arrhythmias, and intracranial hemorrhage). Rarely, hypotension may occur if epinephrine predominates. Diagnosis Biochemical testing: Plasma or urine-fractionated catecholamines/ metanephrines (most sensitive). Imaging: CT, MRI (T2-weighted, gadolinium for extra-adrenal), PET (68Ga-DOTATATE PET) for tumor localization. Genetic screening is advised for young-onset, multifocal, extra-adrenal, or metastatic tumors. Treatment Surgical removal: Adrenalectomy (partial or total); preserve adrenal cortex to avoid Addison’s disease. Medical management: Preoperative blood pressure control below 160/90 mmHg is essential. Alpha-adrenergic blockers : Phenoxybenzamine (non-selective, preferred) to prevent hypertensive crises; prazosin/ phentolamine for paroxysms; liberal salt and hydration to avoid orthostasis. Beta blockers : Added after alpha blockade. Other antihypertensives: Calcium channel blockers and ACE inhibitors. Intraoperative BP control with nitroprusside if necessary. Metastatic Paraganglioma: Treatment options include surgery, alpha-blockers, chemotherapy, radiotherapy, and nuclear medicine therapy (e.g., 131I-MIBG). Nitroprusside infusion (Option C): Nitroprusside can rapidly lower blood pressure, but it is typically used during intraoperative management when blood pressure fluctuations occur due to tumor manipulation. It is not suitable for pre-surgical preparation because it does not address the underlying catecholamine surge. Propranolol (Option D): Beta-blockers like propranolol should not be used alone in the initial management of pheochromocytomas or paragangliomas. Administering beta-blockers without prior alpha-blockade can precipitate a hypertensive crisis due to unopposed alpha-adrenergic activity. Labetalol (Option A): While labetalol has both alpha and beta-blocking properties, it is not the first choice in this scenario. Beta-blockers can cause unopposed

questions.question: What is the most sensitive diagnostic test for detecting pheochromocytoma?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Plasma-fractionated metanephrines Explanation : Plasma-fractionated metanephrines: The most accurate and commonly used test to diagnose pheochromocytoma, detecting elevated levels of catecholamine metabolites. Most sensitive is plasma fractionated metanephrines Most specific is urinary total metanephrines, Generally, 24-hour urine fractionated metanephrines is done first- a 3-fold increase is highly suggestive In case of borderline increase, we can do a plasma-free metanephrine, rule out a history of drugs or do a clonidine suppression test Plasma renin activity (Option A): Used to assess the renin-angiotensin system, often in cases of suspected hyperaldosteronism, not pheochromocytoma. Serum aldosterone levels (Option C): Measures aldosterone, related to adrenal hyperplasia or adenoma, not pheochromocytoma. Syntropin test (Option D): Used to assess adrenal insufficiency by stimulating cortisol production, not relevant for diagnosing pheochromocytoma. Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Pages 2976-2979.

questions.question: A 45-year-old woman presents with episodic headaches, sweating, and palpitations. She has been experiencing high blood pressure that is difficult to control despite multiple antihypertensive medications. On physical examination, her heart rate is 100 beats per minute, and her blood pressure is 180/110 mmHg.Laboratory studies reveal elevated plasma-free metanephrines. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Pheochromocytoma Explanation : Pheochromocytoma : Classic triad of episodic headaches, sweating, and palpitations with resistant hypertension, elevated plasma metanephrines, and an adrenal mass. Pheochromocytoma: Description Pheochromocytomas are rare tumors arising from chromaffin cells of the adrenal medulla. The clinical features result from excessive secretion of catecholamines. Etiopathogenesis These tumors can be benign or malignant and are frequently associated with familial syndromes like neurofibromatosis type 1, multiple endocrine neoplasia type II, and Von-Hippel Lindau disease. Catecholamines are produced in the chromaffin cells starting with the rate-limiting step of tyrosine hydroxylase (TH), regulating the conversion of tyrosine to dihydroxyphenylalanine (DOPA). Pheochromocytomas release these catecholamines in various patterns ranging from paroxysmal, continuous, and mixed patterns. Histopathology Histology of the lesion characteristically shows zellballen nests of chromaffin cells with strong positivity to chromogranin, synaptophysin, CD56, and focally to S100. The presence of chromaffin cells in the extra-adrenal tissue is the only pathognomonic characteristic of the malignant form of the entity. Clinical features Classical triad: Episode of palpitation + Headache +Profuse sweating Dominant sign is Hypertension- 40% have sustained hypertension Tachycardia Anxiety Subcutaneous neurofibromas Cafe-au-lait macules Thyroid mass Axillary freckling Lisch nodules on the iris Retinal angiomas Abdominal mass Diagnosis Diagnosis of pheochromocytoma can be established by biochemical confirmation of hypersecretion of metanephrines and catecholamines. 24-hour urine test Catecholamines Fractionated metanephrines Total metanephrines Plasma tests Catecholamines Free metanephrines Imaging : CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis to locate the tumor. 18F-FDG PET scanning is recommended for metastatic disease. MIBG scintigraphy Somatostatin receptor scintigraphy Gallium DOTATATE PET scanning Treatment The definitive treatment of pheochromocytoma is surgical resection. Blood pressure is controlled by alpha-adrenergic blockers (phenoxybenzamine 0.5-4 mg/kg of body weight) Oral Prazosin or IV phentolamine can be used to control paroxysm. Unilateral Pheochromocytoma: Minimally invasive adrenalectomy Open adrenalectomy Bilateral pheochromocytomas: Bilateral partial or cortical sparing adrenalectomy (open or laparoscopic) Complications Myocardial infarction Cardiogenic shock Renal Failure Pulmonary edema Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) Lactic acidosis Hypertensive retinopathy Hypertensive encephalopathy Hyperaldosteronism (Option A): Causes resistant hypertension and hypokalemia, but lacks the episodic symptoms (headaches, sweating, palpitations) seen in pheochromocytoma. Hyperthyroidism (Option C): Causes palpitations and tachycardia, but typically lacks severe hypertension or episodic nature of symptoms, and no adrenal mass is present. Postural Tachycardia Syndrome (POTS) (Option D): Involves

questions.question: Which of the following genetic conditions are associated with pheochromocytomas?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Neurofibromatosis type 1 Explanation: Pheochromocytoma is associated with NF1 , a genetic disorder causing tumours of nerve tissues. Pheochromocytoma: Description Pheochromocytomas are rare tumors arising from chromaffin cells of the adrenal medulla. The clinical features result from excessive secretion of catecholamines. Epidemiology Estimated to occur in 2 to 8 of 1 million persons per year. The mean age at diagnosis is 40 years, although the tumours can occur from early childhood until late in life. The classic ‘rule of tens’ is 10% bilateral, 10% extra-adrenal (Paragangliomas), and 10% metastatic. It is not used nowadays. Etiopathogenesis These tumors can be benign or malignant and are frequently associated with familial syndromes like Neurofibromatosis type 1, multiple endocrine neoplasia type II, and Von-Hippel Lindau disease. Catecholamines are produced in the chromaffin cells starting with the rate-limiting step of tyrosine hydroxylase (TH), regulating the conversion of tyrosine to dihydroxyphenylalanine (DOPA). Pheochromocytomas release these catecholamines in various patterns ranging from paroxysmal, continuous, and mixed patterns. Norepinephrine is released continuously and can result in persistent hypertension, while epinephrine is released in a paroxysmal pattern resulting in tachyarrhythmias. Ryanodine-2 receptors (RyR2). Beta-2 adrenoceptors Alpha(1)-adrenoreceptors Histopathology Histology of the lesion characteristically shows zellballen nests of chromaffin cells with strong positivity to chromogranin, synaptophysin, CD56, and focally to S100. The presence of chromaffin cells in the extra-adrenal tissue is the only pathognomonic characteristic of the malignant form of the entity. Clinical features Classical triad Episode of palpitation Headache Profuse sweating Dominant sign is Hypertension Tachycardia Anxiety Subcutaneous neurofibromas Cafe-au-lait macules Thyroid mass Axillary freckling Lisch nodules on the iris Retinal angiomas Abdominal mass Diagnosis Diagnosis of pheochromocytoma can be established by biochemical confirmation of hypersecretion of metanephrines and catecholamines. 24-hour urine test Catecholamines Fractionated metanephrines Total metanephrines Imaging : CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis to locate the tumor. 18F-FDG PET scanning is recommended for metastatic disease. MIBG scintigraphy Somatostatin receptor scintigraphy Gallium DOTATATE PET scanning Differential Diagnosis Hyperthyroidism Renal artery stenosis Hyperaldosteronism Cardiomyopathy Postural tachycardia syndrome (POTS) Treatment The definitive treatment of pheochromocytoma is surgical resection. Preoperative preparation of the patient has to be considered, and blood pressure should be consistently < 160/90 mm Hg. Blood pressure is controlled by alpha-adrenergic blockers(phenoxybenzamine 0.5-4 mg/kg of body weight) Oral Prazosin or IV phentolamine can be used to control paroxysm. Unilateral Pheochromocytoma: Minimally invasive adrenalectomy: Preferred treatment for most unilateral adrenal pheochromocytomas. Open adrenalectomy Bilateral pheochromocytomas: Bilateral total adrenalectomy is associated with a lifelong need for steroid replacement with long-term side effects. Bilateral partial or cortical sparing adrenalectomy (open or laparoscopic) Complications Myocardial infarction Cardiogenic shock Renal Failure Pulmonary edema Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) Lactic acidosis Hypertensive retinopathy Hypertensive encephalopathy Marfan syndrome (Option A): Primarily affects

questions.question: A 45-year-old woman presents with persistent hypertension, weight gain, and muscle weakness. Her laboratory results reveal elevated cortisol levels and suppressed ACTH. Imaging studies show an adrenal mass, as shown below. Which of the following layers of the adrenal gland is most likely responsible for the hormone excess in this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Zona fasciculata Explanation: The patient's clinical presentation, including elevated cortisol, suppressed ACTH, and the presence of an adrenal mass, suggests a cortisol-secreting adrenal tumor and Zona fasciculata of the adrenal cortex produces glucocorticoids, mainly cortisol. Excess cortisol is responsible for the symptoms of hypertension, weight gain, and muscle weakness. Layers of Adrenal Gland Zona glomerulosa (Option A ruled out) The outermost layer of the cortex. It secretes aldosterone, a mineralocorticoid that regulates sodium retention and potassium and proton excretion. Aldosterone production is mainly stimulated by angiotensin II, which is part of the renin-angiotensin system- This is not under the control of ACTH. Zona fasciculata (Option B) The middle layer of the cortex secretes cortisol. It also secretes adrenal androgens. An adrenal mass in this layer could cause increased cortisol production, resulting in symptoms such as hypertension,

questions.question: What is the key difference in the bloodwork between primary and secondary Addison's disease?

options.A: High renin levels in secondary Addison's
options.B: Low aldosterone levels in secondary Addison's
options.C: Low ACTH levels in secondary Addison's

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Low ACTH levels in secondary Addison's Explanation: In secondary Addison's disease, the problem lies with the pituitary gland , leading to low levels of ACTH (adrenocorticotropic hormone). Secondary or Central Addison disease Commonly occurs due to exogenous steroid administration, resulting in the suppression of ACTH synthesis. Secondary adrenal insufficiency is a pituitary-dependent loss of ACTH secretion, which reduces glucocorticoid production. Causes: Sheehan syndrome - M/C Obstetric cause Simmonds disease or pituitary cachexia Pituitary disorders (tumours, surgery, radiation). Long-term corticosteroid use leads to suppression of the hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal (HPA) axis. Pituitary irradiation Pituitary haemorrhage Pituitary infiltration Symptoms : Fatigue, weakness, weight loss, nausea, vomiting, hypotension. No skin hyperpigmentation, unlike primary Addison's Alabaster coloured pale skin due to deficiency of POMC-derived peptides. Diagnosis : Administration of cosyntropin(ACTH) to assess adrenal function: Low cortisol with low-normal ACTH. ACTH stimulation test shows a blunted cortisol response. Normal renin Normal aldosterone mL Treatment : Glucocorticoid replacement (hydrocortisone or prednisone). Hydrocortisone of 15-25mg in 2-3 divided doses. Treat the underlying pituitary cause if present. High renin levels in secondary Addison's (Option A): Renin is usually normal; high renin occurs in primary Addison's. Low aldosterone levels in secondary Addison's (Option B): Aldosterone is normal in secondary Addison's; low in primary. Elevated potassium in secondary Addison's (Option D): Potassium is typically normal in secondary; elevated in primary. Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page 2970-2972.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is false? deficiency

options.A: Random plasma cortisol of >500 nmol/L excludes adrenal insufficiency
options.B: Plasma renin will be high in mineralocorticoid deficiency
options.C: Aldosterone level will be low or in the lower part of the reference range in mineralocorticoid

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) None of the above Explanation: Addison's Disease-Primary Adrenocortical Failure: Investigations Random plasma cortisol measurement (values >500 nmol/L exclude adrenal insufficiency) (Option A ruled out). Short ACTH stimulation test- if random cortisol levels are between 100-500, 1 microgram ACTH, serum cortisol levels of <500 is considered confirmatory for adrenal insufficiency Plasma renin and aldosterone (high renin with low/lower part of the reference range aldosterone in mineralocorticoid deficiency) (Options B & C ruled out). Dehydroepiandrosterone sulfate (DHEAS) and androstenedione in women Adrenal autoantibodies for autoimmune causes; imaging (CT/MRI) if antibodies are negative. Management 1. Glucocorticoid Replacement: Oral hydrocortisone is preferred, and Prednisolone and dexamethasone may also be used. 2. Mineralocorticoid Replacement: Fludrocortisone Addisonian Crisis An Addisonian crisis is a life-threatening medical emergency that occurs when there is a severe deficiency of cortisol and aldosterone. It is most commonly seen in people with Addison's disease (primary adrenal insufficiency), especially when their hormone replacement therapy is inadequate or missed or during periods of extreme stress (e.g., illness, trauma, or surgery). Management: IV Hydrocortisone Reference: Davidson's Principles and Practice of Medicine 24th edition, pages 672-673

questions.question: Which of the following is not a clinical feature of Addison’s disease?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) ACTH insufficiency Explanation: ACTH is excess in Addison’s disease. Addison's disease refers to primary adrenocortical failure : Etiology Autoimmune: M/C/C Worldwide Sporadic Polyglandular syndromes Tuberculosis: M/C/C in India Histoplasmosis HIV/AIDS Metastatic carcinoma Bilateral adrenalectomy Clinical Features Glucocorticoid insufficiency (Option A ruled out) : Weight loss, anorexia, malaise, weakness, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea or constipation, postural hypotension, shock, hypoglycemia, hyponatremia (dilutional), hypercalcemia Mineralocorticoid insufficiency (Option B ruled out) : Hypotension, shock, hyponatremia, hyperkalemia ACTH excess (Option C) : Pigmentation Adrenal androgen insufficiency (Option D ruled out) : Decreased body hair and loss of libido, especially in females Reference: Davidson's Principles and Practice of Medicine, 24th edition, pages 671-672

questions.question: Which part of the kidney is affected in Gordon syndrome?

options.C: Ascending limb of the loop of Henle
options.D: Descending limb of the loop of Henle

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Distal nephron Explanation: Pseudohypoaldosteronism type II (PHA II) or Gordon syndrome: Inheritance Autosomal dominant (mostly) Pathogenesis Mutations in the WNK1, WNK4, CUL3, or KLHL3 genes result in abnormalities in serine/threonine kinases that dysregulate the thiazide-sensitive sodium-chloride cotransporter (NCC) in the distal nephron (Option A). This leads to increased sodium and chloride reabsorption, causing extracellular volume expansion and subsequent hypertension. Clinical Presentation Non-specific symptoms like muscle weakness, fatigue, hypertension (not always) Laboratory Findings Hyperkalemia Hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis Hypercalciuria Low or low-normal plasma renin activity Low serum aldosterone levels (relative to hyperkalemia) Normal kidney function/normal glomerular filtration Management Correction of electrolyte abnormalities Salt restriction Thiazide diuretics Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC10874887/

questions.question: All of the following are clinical manifestations of Liddle’s syndrome except?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Hyperaldosteronism Explanation: Aldosterone levels are suppressed in Liddle’s syndrome. Liddle’s syndrome (pseudohyperaldosteronism): Definition An autosomal dominant genetic disorder characterized by hypertension with hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis, hyporeninemia, and suppressed aldosterone secretion Pathophysiology Mutations in SCNN1A, SCNN1B, and SCNN1G genes → α , β , and γ subunits of ENaC (Epithelial Sodium Channel) altered → Increased Epithelial Sodium Channel activity → Elevated sodium reabsorption in the distal nephron → Sodium retention Clinical features - Early-onset hypertension (as early as 2 years of age) (Option C ruled out) - Hypokalemia (Option A ruled out) and metabolic alkalosis - Suppressed plasma renin (Option B ruled out) and aldosterone levels (Option D) - Fatigue, muscle weakness, dizziness, and vision changes Management - Potassium-sparing diuretics: Amiloride or Triamterene - Salt restriction Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6731958/

questions.question: A 45-year-old woman presents to the clinic with complaints of persistent high blood pressure and muscle weakness. She has a history of hypertension that has been difficult to control with standard antihypertensive medications. On examination, her blood pressure is 160/95 mmHg, and she has mild generalized muscle weakness. Her laboratory results show: Serum potassium: 3.2 mEq/L Serum sodium: 142 mEq/L Which of the following drugs can be used in hyperaldosteronism?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) All of the above Explanation: All of these drugs are used in hyperaldosteronism Hyperaldosteronism: Investigations Serum electrolytes - Hypokalaemia - Sodium: Upper end of normal reference range in primary hyperaldosteronism, low in secondary hyperaldosteronism Other tests - Plasma renin activity is low and aldosterone concentration is high representing a positive screening test - Aldosterone: Renin Ratio (ARR) - Saline infusion test- Aldosterone levels are high even after 2L infusion over 4 hours, which is confirmatory. - Suppression tests (sodium loading) - Stimulation tests (captopril or furosemide) - Adrenal Vein Catheterisation - CT/MRI- IOC Management Medical Management - Mineralocorticoid receptor antagonists: Spironolactone, Eplerenone (risk of gynecomastia in 20% of males with spironolactone). - Amiloride Surgical Management - Adrenalectomy Reference: Davidson's Principles and Practice of Medicine, 24th edition, pages 673-674

questions.question: A 50-year-old male with a history of hypertension presents with muscle weakness and frequent headaches. On examination, his blood pressure is 165/95 mmHg, and laboratory tests reveal hypokalemia. Further evaluation shows suppressed plasma renin activity and elevated plasma aldosterone concentration. Which of the following is the most likely clinical feature associated with this condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Metabolic alkalosis Explanation: Hyperaldosteronism often causes metabolic alkalosis due to excessive hydrogen ion loss in the kidneys as aldosterone promotes sodium reabsorption and hydrogen ion excretion. This leads to an alkalotic state, which is consistent with the elevated aldosterone levels and clinical presentation in this patient. Clinical Features of Hyperaldosteronism Hypertension : Hallmark of hyperaldosteronism, often resistant to conventional treatments. Aldosterone's sodium-retaining effects lead to increased fluid volume and blood pressure. (Option C ruled out) Hypokalemia : Excessive aldosterone promotes potassium excretion in the kidneys, resulting in hypokalemia. This can manifest as muscle weakness, even paralysis. Notably, not all patients with primary aldosteronism exhibit hypokalemia. Metabolic Alkalosis: Aldosterone promotes hydrogen ion excretion and bicarbonate retention , contributing to metabolic alkalosis. Symptoms may include muscle cramps and tetany i n severe cases. (Option A) Other Features: Hyperaldosteronism is also associated with increased risks of: Cardiovascular disease Kidney damage Osteoporosis Type 2 diabetes Cognitive dysfunction Hypernatremia (Option B): While aldosterone increases sodium reabsorption, it usually does not cause hypernatremia due to a compensatory increase in water retention through other mechanisms, such as antidiuretic hormone (ADH) activity. Thus, serum sodium levels often remain normal. Increased plasma renin activity (Option D): In primary hyperaldosteronism, plasma renin activity is typically suppressed due to negative feedback from elevated aldosterone levels. Elevated renin activity would be more suggestive of secondary hyperaldosteronism or other causes of hypertension. Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page 349, 350, 365, 2078, 2079, 2965, 2987, 3162, 3165.

questions.question: A 42-year-old female presents with persistent hypertension and hypokalemia despite being on multiple antihypertensive medications. Laboratory findings reveal suppressed plasma renin activity and elevated plasma aldosterone concentration. Her imaging studies are unremarkable, showing no adrenal masses. Genetic testing later reveals a KCNJ5 gene mutation. Which of the following conditions is most likely responsible for her hyperaldosteronism?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Familial hyperaldosteronism type II (FH-II) Explanation : Familial hyperaldosteronism type II (FH-II) is associated with mutations such as KCNJ5, which affects the function of potassium channels and leads to excess aldosterone secretion. Patients with FH-II present with primary hyperaldosteronism (persistent hypertension, hypokalemia, and elevated aldosterone levels). The presence of the KCNJ5 mutation confirms Familial hyperaldosteronism type II (FH-II) in this patient. Primary Hyperaldosteronism Adrenal abnormalities: Arises due to dysfunction within the adrenal glands. Aldosterone-producing adenomas (APAs) : Benign tumors that account for about 60% of cases . These adenomas often contain somatic mutations (e.g., KCNJ5, ATP1A1, ATP2B3), which stimulate aldosterone synthase (CYP11B2) Idiopathic hyperaldosteronism (IHA) : Bilateral adrenal hyperplasia is responsible for around 40% of cases. Primary (Unilateral) Adrenal Hyperplasia (PAH): It typically lacks genetic mutations such as KCNJ5 , which is linked to familial hyperaldosteronism type II (FH-II). (Option A ruled out) Adrenal carcinoma: A rare cause that involves autonomous overproduction of aldosterone and/or deoxycorticosterone (DOC). Genetic Causes : Familial Hyperaldosteronism Type I (FH-I): Also known as glucocorticoid-remediable aldosteronism (GRA). A genetic fusion on chromosome 8 makes aldosterone synthesis ACTH-dependent. It is treatable with glucocorticoids. (Option B ruled out) Familial Hyperaldosteronism Type II (FH-II) and III (FH-III): Linked to mutations (e.g., KCNJ5), leading to increased aldosterone secretion via increased sodium permeability. (Option C) Secondary Hyperaldosteronism Causes: Triggered by conditions activating the renin-angiotensin system , which increases aldosterone production. Malignant hypertension Renin-secreting tumors Renal artery stenosis Hypovolemia Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page 349, 350, 365, 2078, 2079, 2965, 2987, 3162, 3165.

questions.question: A 30-year-old man presents with episodes of severe headaches, palpitations, and sweating. His blood pressure is consistently elevated, and during an episode, it spikes to 190/110 mmHg. Laboratory findings reveal elevated levels of catecholamines in the plasma and urine. Imaging studies confirm a mass in the adrenal gland. Which of the following hormones is most likely being secreted in excess due to the adrenal medullary mass?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Adrenaline Explanation : The adrenal medulla secretes catecholamines such as adrenaline (epinephrine) and noradrenaline (norepinephrine). Epinephrine is 80%, 18 % norepinephrine and 2 % dopamine A mass in the adrenal medulla, such as a pheochromocytoma , can cause excessive secretion of these hormones, leading to episodic hypertension, palpitations, and sweating, as seen in this patient. Aldosterone (Option A) : Aldosterone is produced by the zona glomerulosa of the adrenal cortex, not the adrenal medulla. It regulates sodium and potassium balance. Cortisol (Option B): Cortisol is produced by the zona fasciculata of the adrenal cortex. Excess cortisol would lead to symptoms such as weight gain, muscle weakness, and hyperglycemia, which are not the primary symptoms in this patient. Androgens (Option D): Androgens are produced mainly by the zona reticularis of the adrenal cortex, not the medulla. Excess androgens may cause virilization but would not lead to the severe hypertensive episodes and catecholamine elevation described in this patient. Reference: Davidson's Principles and Practice of Medicine, 24th edition, Page 665, 666, 675. Physiology, Adrenal Gland - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf.
